item.title: -ing vs -ed distinction
item.description: Observed by Sellars to be responsible for a lot of philosophical confusion. Most interesting philosophical concepts come with a “-ing”/ “-ed” distinction that’s crucial to understand the nature of.

item.title: Analytic philosophy
item.description: Often the task of analytic philosophy is to take statements in some potentially-problematic vocabulary and give them an explanation in terms of some preferred or unproblematic vocabulary.

item.title: Anti-descriptivism
item.description: Opposition to descriptivism. [-@@scharp2012wilfrid] Relevant figures: Saul Kripke Hilary Putnam David Kaplan Wilfrid Sellars Topics: semantic externalism epistemological externalism functionalism direct reference the relation between conceivability and possibility Consequences:

item.title: Autonomous discursive practice
item.description: “A language game you could play if you played no other” TODO

item.title: Classical logic
item.description: In classical logic, the law of the excluded middle obtains. When this is removed, one obtains Intuitionistic logic.

item.title: Deontology
item.description: TODO

item.title: Doxastic modality
item.description: A type of modality that concerns obligation and permission.

item.title: Duhem-Quine thesis
item.description: Named after Pierre Duhem and Quine: It is impossible to test a scientific hypothesis in isolation, because an empirical test of the hypothesis requires one or more background assumptions.

item.title: Empiricism
item.description: Often contrasted with rationalism and naturalism.

item.title: Having a nature or a history
item.description: When introduced to a new concept, do you prefer to be given a definition for it in terms of other concepts, or do you prefer a story of how the word came to be used as it’s used?

item.title: Hesperus and Phosphorus
item.description: From Wikipedia These are puzzles posed by Frege. They are addressed by making a distinction between sense and reference. First puzzle The brightest star in morning was called Hesperus, and the brightest star of evening was called Phosphorus.

item.title: Is-ought problem
item.description: The is-ought problem. David Hume. The infeasibility of reducing “ought talk” to “is talk” is the same problem (according to Sellars) as reducing “the personal” (e.

item.title: Myth of the Given
item.description: Author A (semantic) holist argument against meaning-givenness, like Quines’ Myth of the Museum against sense-givenness. It is common to think that knowledge begins with experience - that there are particular experiences (raw sense data) that are privileged as certain, leading to a desire to cache out all semantic interpretations of other thoughts in terms of these certain experiences (otherwise they are nonsense).

item.title: Myth of the Museum
item.description: Uncritical semantics is the myth of a museum in which the exhibits are meanings and the words are labels. To switch languages is to change the labels.

item.title: Naturalism
item.description: TODO

item.title: Nonmonotonic logic
item.description: Monotonicity is a property of the entailment relation of a logic.

item.title: Norm-fact dualism
item.description: A dualism. A problem for those who try to address the problem of Cartesian dualism by appealing to the normative character of intentionality.

item.title: Ontology
item.description: The theory of what really is, or the what is there ‘objectively’.

item.title: Possible worlds semantics
item.description: Possible worlds semantics is a semantics for Modal logic.

item.title: Pragmatism, Relativism, and Irrationalism
item.description: Author [-@rorty2020pragmatism]

item.title: Rationalism
item.description: Often contrasted with empiricism.

item.title: Reference
item.description: Grammar Grammatically, one signals reference with of. E.g.: I’m thinking of a number As a relation Reference has been thought of as a relation between linguistic terms and things in the world.

item.title: Representation
item.description: Representation is a theory of the relation between appearance and reality. A successor concept to theories of resemblance Premodern theories understood relation between appearance and reality in terms of resemblance (sharing properties).

item.title: Representation regress
item.description: If any things are known representationally, then some things must be known nonrepresentationally (immediately, by being had or grasped). Otherwise we can’t know about something via a representation $R$, because we’d need another representation to know $R$.

item.title: Representationalism
item.description: A theory of semantics, closely related to descriptivism: to be cognitively contentful is to be representing the world. E.g. proper names represent without being descriptions, in Naming and Necessity.

item.title: Rigid designator
item.description: Saul Kripke’s theory of the meaning of names (from Naming and Necessity) that is alternative to descriptivism: A name refers to the same object in all possible worlds in which that object exists, and the name never refers to anything else.

item.title: Semantic skepticism
item.description: A Kantian insight: the real problematic skepticism is semantic skepticism. He doesn’t take it for granted that we can ‘represent’ reality and merely have to worry about whether or not that representation is true.

item.title: Sense vs reference
item.description: The distinction between sense and reference is attributed to Frege.

item.title: Theoretical and practical
item.description: This is a Kantian distinction. e.g. theoretical vs practical reason, theoretical vs practical necessity. theoretical necessity: rules of nature practical necessity: rules of thought
